comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
There is nothing like a good ol' tug, and the 'Phoenix'  looks like one of the best.  I like the sense of movement from the fluttering flags.  Does the one on the mast mean "2" ?

Apart from a few scratches on the hull, she looks fairly new, so this photo is c.1900?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: I think we might need a tugboat and/or flag expert to help out here, beachcomberaustralia!

comment.author: 33102966@N06
comment._content:
A magnificent craft.....I wonder whatever happened to it ?
Are there any historical records of the 'Phoenix' other than your record ?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33102966@N06] We have two other photos of the "Phoenix" here and here - I'm sure you'd find more in an Internet search. Picture Australia would be a good place to start. AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I did a little bit of Troving - A collision on Lake Macquarie in 1912 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15384067 A later photo / postcard of the 'Phoenix' at Patonga (c.1910 from the ladies' clothes) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=73817# Beached at Brooklyn 1927 - described as being owned by Mr J. Izzard, and operating on the Hawkesbury between Brooklyn, Palm Beach, and Newport. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16412926 Brought back to Sydney for repairs - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16413262 After that . . .?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And another photo at Brooklyn railway (c.1910) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823320&am... (from this album - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=71850#
